text: How many syndicates like will and seamless do you think we compete with each day? He mentions 15 PhD’s on the team! Makes me wonder how some of us 1 man bands are able to compete !

elements.text: How many syndicates like will and seamless do you think we compete with each day? He mentions 15 PhD’s on the team! Makes me wonder how some of us 1 man bands are able to compete !

text: Not to demean education it but a Phd can be very overrated and I think if people really knew what it takes to get one and some of the internal "tricks" that supervisors use to get their students over the finish line, they would be both shocked and appalled. I am sure its not the case at top instutitions but places lower down the foodchain dodgy things certainly happen. I've personally found my Phd to be way more of a hindrance to me than a help in this game but that could be down to subject area and it could be due to my own shortcomings and incompetence. Others may disagree here but I wasted literally years trying fancy stuff that never worked based on knowledge I had acquired that I thought could be applied - again though, lack of success could be down to my own shortcomings. I did a masters degree in statistics and that has been WAY more useful.

Others may disagree here but I wasted literally years trying fancy stuff that never worked based on knowledge I had acquired that I thought could be applied - again though, lack of success could be down to my own shortcomings. I did a masters degree in statistics and that has been WAY more useful.

elements.text: I was just thinking whatever they come up with would need to be very scalable to pay off a team of 15 Phds!!

text: I suppose "who" your competition is often depends on the scalability of your operation - my overall turnover is very low despite my current strategies looking like they can't really be scaled that much further (and any additional capacity is still small with regards to the big picture), so I doubt I am competing with anyone doing this full time. Obviously we are all after value but whenever I spot value there isn't very much available at all to make it worthwhile for 15 PhDs.

text: <@UBS7QANF3> How do syndicates work? Do the employees generally prefer a salary each month vs the risk of going it alone or do some have some sort of profit share?

elements.text: How do syndicates work? Do the employees generally prefer a salary each month vs the risk of going it alone or do some have some sort of profit share?

text: I suppose it opens up an interesting question. Given 15 employees with a Phd do they all work together on one thing under someone managing a project, or would they be off as solo players trying to develop their own profitable strategies to cover more surface area in the markets? If the former, must be a tough taks from a management perspective.

elements.text: I suppose it opens up an interesting question. text: I guess one question I had which maybe I missed is, how do you scale up and bring people in without giving away your model. How do you incentivize and prevent them from leaving and doing it themselves?

elements.text: I guess one question I had which maybe I missed is, how do you scale up and bring people in without giving away your model. How do you incentivize and prevent them from leaving and doing it themselves?

text: There's a distinction to be made between employees and syndicate members. I would not expect employees to get much if any profit share

text: I guess it depends. Most academic types I have encountered do what they do for love of the subject alone. That said I most of those worked in a uni and I have never met anyone with Phd working in a finance/gambling related field. A "typical" uni academic type would have no problem working on an isolated project without any thought about if it would make them money or not.

text: I think the way that bigger players have to operate often puts them in a different space from individuals so there's not necessarily much direct competition. <@UBS7QANF3> is a good example - he's using data feeds that most of us wouldn't even contemplate to bet at very specific moments when most of us probably wouldn't be betting, so the competition with an individual automated player might not be that great. Big operations can seem scary, especially if you're just finding out about them for the first time but the truth is they have always been there. They're just another part of the ecosystem.

elements.text: I think the way that bigger players have to operate often puts them in a different space from individuals so there's not necessarily much direct competition.

text: Syndicates reduce the per head fixed costs like curating data sources, and splits the ancilliary dev like monitoring and reporting. So it's not just a case of setting up in your back bedroom when you see their model because the cost of running it on your own might well outstrip what it earns, even if you have the time do all it involves. Being a one-man-band at any job is tougher than having a team, especially balancing doing the work and looking for the next work, probably where syndicates excel. We'd all like someone else to do the stats and the coding so we can muse all day, Voila! A business is born, but it's sports betting so let's call it a syndicate.

elements.text: Syndicates reduce the per head fixed costs like curating data sources, and splits the ancilliary dev like monitoring and reporting. So it's not just a case of setting up in your back bedroom when you see their model because the cost of running it on your own might well outstrip what it earns, even if you have the time do all it involves. Being a one-man-band at any job is tougher than having a team, especially balancing doing the work and looking for the next work, probably where syndicates excel. We'd all like someone else to do the stats and the coding so we can muse all day, Voila! A business is born, but it's sports betting so let's call it a syndicate.
